# Introduction

<!-- ----------------------------------------------------------------- -->
## Motivation
- Precise small area estimates critical for effective health policy and interventions.
- Small area analysis: Descriptive, exploratory, and causal methods to improve resource allocation and decision-making.
- Focus on Australia: Challenges due to population density and geographic disparities

<!-- ----------------------------------------------------------------- -->
---

- Bayesian inference for disease mapping and small area estimation enhances decision-making and addresses data sparsity.
- Addressing limitations in current Bayesian small-area modelling to overcome sparsity and improve accuracy.

- Aim: Develop statistical approaches for better health data resolution and targeted interventions.

<!-- ----------------------------------------------------------------- -->
## Research Problem

The overarching research problem in this project is to develop and apply Bayesian small area methods to health data in Australia.

<!-- ----------------------------------------------------------------- -->
## Aims and Objectives
:::{.incremental}
- **1.0:** <span class="blB">Small area estimation</span>
  - **1.1 Method:** Develop a Bayesian SAE method for proportions, which specifically tackles data sparsity for improved resolution and reach.
  - **1.2 Application:** Generate SA2-level prevalence estimates for several cancer risk factors across Australia with appropriate measures of uncertainty.
:::

<!-- ----------------------------------------------------------------- -->
---

:::{.incremental}
- **2.0:** <span class="blB">Index creation</span>
  - **2.1 Method:** Develop a Bayesian model-based approach to index creation that can accommodate spatial autocorrelation and known heteroscedastic measurement error.
  - **2.2 Application:** Using cancer risk factor data, create the first area-level cancer risk factor indices for Australia. The indices will have appropriate measures of uncertainty.
:::

<!-- ----------------------------------------------------------------- -->
---

:::{.incremental}
- **3.0:**  <span class="blB">Burden of disease</span>
  - **3.1 Method:** Drawing from the SAE and disease mapping literature, explore and develop appropriate Bayesian spatiotemporal methods to model the wide range of health data used in full BOD studies.
  - **3.2 Application:** Using two very different diseases (coronary heart disease (CHD) and asthma in Western Australia), generate and map the first small area level BOD estimates in Australia.
:::

## Proposed approach {.scrollable}

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="48%"}

- Stage 1 (TSLN-S1)
  - Fit a **individual-level** <span class="blB">logistic model</span> to the survey data
- Stage 1 (S1) estimates
  - Using fitted values calculate area-level <span class="blB">S1 estimates</span> and sampling variances
- Stage 2 (TSLN-S2)
  - **Smooth** <span class="blB">S1 estimates</span> and **impute** estimates for non-sampled areas using an **area-level** <span class="blB">FH model</span>
:::
